member.name: T:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.AbstractCollectionTypeProto
member.summary: Base class for a type proto handler that can deal with collections.
member.remarks:
Collection of collections is not supported. However, descendands may use own (de)serialization approach to handle nested collections.
All descendants of this class must implement a constructor which accepts a single argument: the type of the collection. Constructor can throw if passed type is unacceptable.

member.name: T:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.ConfigNodePatch
member.summary: Class that describes how to modify a part's config node.
member.remarks: IMPORTANT! Every patch must be designed so that if it matched to a part and was applied to, it won't match to the same patched part again. If this condition doesn't stand, then the engine will disable the patch.

member.summary: Config URL path from which the pacth was created (if any).

member.name: F:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.ConfigNodePatch.name
member.summary: Name of the patch. It must be unique in the game's scope.

member.name: F:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.ConfigNodePatch.loadContext
member.summary: Context in which this patch should be applied.

member.name: F:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.ConfigNodePatch.verboseLogging
member.summary: Tells if all patch processing job must be logged.
member.remarks: Use it to debug your patch. The logs may get noisy and large though.

member.name: F:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.ConfigNodePatch.modName
member.summary: Name of the mod's assembly which owns the part being patched.
member.remarks:
This mod must be installed into the game. Othewrise, the patch will be ignored. If the patch needs to run regardless to the mod installed (e.g. when deleting the parts), simply leave this value empty.
The patches with empty mod name are always handled first, assuming they are designed to drop the incompatible parts. Don't make "fix" patches with empty mod name since their order of applying will be random.

member.name: F:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.ConfigNodePatch.patchCreationTimestamp
member.summary: Unix Epoch timestamp of when the patch was created.
member.remarks: It doesn't need to be precise. The main goal of this timestamp is to order patches on the same part. The patches created earlier will be applied first. This timestamp can also be used to determine when it makes sense to drop it from the distribution, e.g. if it's too old and not relevant anymore.

member.name: T:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.ConfigNodePatch.TestSection
member.summary: Config class that specifies how to check if the part qualifies for patching.

member.name: F:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.ConfigNodePatch.TestSection.partTests
member.summary: Part's persited fields to check.
member.remarks: The check is done "one-to-one". In order fro the part to qualify, all its fields must match exactly to the provided values.

member.name: F:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.ConfigNodePatch.TestSection.moduleTests
member.summary: Part modules persisted fields to check.
member.remarks:
The module is found by name, set via field "name". If no index suffix is set, then the first matched module is tested regardless to how many other modules with the same name exist. The following index suffixes can be set to control the module lookup:
",<number>" - requires that the named module must be found at the specific index within the part's persistent state. Index starts from 0.
",+<number>" - skips the specified number of modules with the same name. Use it when multiple modules with the same name are saved.

member.name: T:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.ConfigNodePatch.UpgradeSection
member.summary: Config class that specifies how pacth the qualifying part.

member.name: F:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.ConfigNodePatch.UpgradeSection.partRules
member.summary: Patching rules for the part config.

member.name: F:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.ConfigNodePatch.UpgradeSection.moduleRules
member.summary: Patching rules for the module configs.
member.remarks:
The modules are patched in order. I.e. first module pacth in the upgrade section will be applied to the first module in the part's save state. When the module needs to be skipped from the patch, simply don't provide any rules.
If the part's action is , then the module rules are ignored.

member.name: T:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.ConfigNodePatch.UpgradeSection.Rules
member.summary: Config class that defines patching rules.

member.name: F:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.ConfigNodePatch.UpgradeSection.Rules.name
member.summary: Module name to apply changes to. It can have a lookup suffix.

member.name: F:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.ConfigNodePatch.UpgradeSection.Rules.action
member.summary: Tells what to do with the matched node.

member.name: F:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.ConfigNodePatch.UpgradeSection.Rules.fieldRules
member.summary: Defines the rules to apply to the node's fields if the is .
member.remarks:
The value is comma separated pairs of "name=value". The "name" designates the field name within the persisted module state, and "value" specifies a new value. Field name can have a special prefix symbol that defines a special case or how the new value should be applied:
No prefix. Tells to add a new value. The existing value(s) in the persisted state will not be affected. This can be used to add multiple values to a key.
"-". Tells to erase the value(s) or node(s) at the key. There are no checks done to verify if there is something to delete.
"%". Tells to assign a new value to an existing filed or create a new value if none exists.
The rules are applied in the order they are listed in the patch. It's important to consider it when applying multiple rules to the same key.

member.name: T:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.IPersistentField
member.summary: Interface for the simple types that need custom (de)serialization logic.
member.remarks:
It's similar to IConfigNode interface in the compound types but with the following differences:
The value is (de)serialized from/to a simple string.
If the field is initialized to an instance of the type, then this instance will be used to deserialize the value. If the field is not initialized but there is a value in the config file, then a new instance will be created. For this reason the type must implement a default constructor.
Note that the types that implement this interface will never be treated as compound. I.e. will not try to persist the members of such types even though there may be fields attributed with .

member.remarks: It's OK to throw exceptions if the value cannot be parsed.

member.name: T:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.PersistentFieldsDatabaseAttribute
member.summary: A simple annotation to associate a persistent group with a game's database key.

remarks.para: Each .cfg file in the mod's folders is scanned and indexed by the game on start. The data is stored in the database where it can be accessed from the game. The access is read-only, any changes to the node returned from the database won't affect the database state.

The config file in the database is identified by a key which is made of three major parts:
A file path relative to GameData. ATTENTION: the path must not contain "."!
The config filename without extension.
Node path inside the file starting from the root. I.e. the root node should have name as well.
E.g. key KIS/settings/KISConfig/Global addresses a node KISConfig/Global in file stored at GameData/KIS/settings.cfg.

Special case is subfolders PluginData, they are ignored during database scan. Put there configs that can change during the gameplay. Remember, that even a tiny change in the config will trigger database re-compilation on the next start which may significantly impact game loading time.

Database is actively used by ModuleManager (a.k.a. MM). Be wise when choosing if the fields should be read from a file or from the database. The module manager patches are only applied on the database, they don't affect the config files. E.g. if the part config is expected to be a target of the MM patches but never updated from the gameplay, then reading id via the database is the best choice. However, various mod's settings, that change during the game, will unlikely be a target for a MM patch - put the config into PluginData and read it as a file.

member.name: M:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.PersistentFieldsDatabaseAttribute.#ctor(System.String,System.String)
member.param: An absolute path to the node in the game's database. Note that this must be a path to the config's root. This path is used to find the right settings file, not the right node within a file.
A group of the annotation. When saving or loading the persistent fields only the fields of this group will be considered. Must not be null.

member.name: T:KSPDev.ConfigUtils.PersistentFieldsFileAttribute
member.summary: A simple annotation to associate a persistent group with a configuration file.
member.remarks:
Multiple annotations are allowed on the class. It's not required to have unique filename/nodePath/group set in every annontation but it's highly recommended.
This assignment is ignored in the nested classes. Though, when using nested class as an immediate target of the call the annotation will be handled just fine.

member.name: M:KSPDev.FSUtils.KspPaths.GetModsPath(System.Type)
member.summary: Returns a relative game's path to the mod's root folder.

example.para: Given the mod's assembly was loaded from GameData/ModFolder1/ModFolder2/Plugins/mod.dll, the returned path will be GameData/ModFolder1/ModFolder2/ because of Plugins folder name is considered to be a common name for the mod's binaries.

If the mod's DLL is located in the folder other than Plugins, then just the parent folder is returned. E.g. for GameData/ModFolder1/ModFolder2/MyDLLs/mod.dll, the result would be GameData/ModFolder1/ModFolder2/MyDLLs/.

member.param: The target to resolve the assembly for.
member.returns: An absolute path. There is always a trailing directory separator symbol.

member.name: T:KSPDev.GUIUtils.AbstractHermeticGUIControl
member.summary: Base class for a GUI element that incapsulates a class instance member.
member.remarks:
This kind of controls are used to represent and/or edit the values of various types, but not in the usual OnGUI approach. The usual Unity approach assumes that the value is passed and returned in each rendering call. However, for the hermetic control, the source of the value is defined only once, at the creation time. Once it's done, the rendering is only called to have the logic handled. That said, the caller rendering method doesn't care about the underlying data, and that's why it's "hermetic".
The value source is either a field or a property of the class. Due to the need of using reflections to access the member, these controls are not performance optimized. They are fine for the debugging and settings dialogs, but for the performance demanding applications a regular Unity approach is suggested.

member.name: T:KSPDev.GUIUtils.GUILayoutStringTable
member.summary: Utility class to draw a simple table with the text colum contents.

remarks.para: This table cannot hold non-string content. It keeps all the columns to be of the same, and the size is adjusted to the maximum column's size in the rows. There is a one frame delay between the content change and the column resizing, which may result in flickering if the content changes too frequently. The columns try to take as small space as possible, so defining the minimum size may be a good bet.
This class is designed to be called on every frame. It's heavily performance optimized.

member.name: T:KSPDev.GUIUtils.IsLocalizableModule
member.summary: Generic interface for the modules that manage own localizable items.
member.remarks:
The "item" can be anything. If the module pays special attention to deal with the "items", then it should implement this interface so that the notification could be sent when the language has changed (or updated). Here are some examples of the localizable items:
KSP events, actions or fields that are attributed with . The module would want to call the method to have the strings updated.
Cached strings. The module would want to refresh the cache.
Dynamically created part menu items. The module would want to recreate them. If that's the case it's always better to implement , and then just call the update method.

member.name: M:KSPDev.GUIUtils.IsLocalizableModule.LocalizeModule
member.summary: A callback which is called when the localization vesion has changed.

remarks.para: This method can be called before the module is fully initialized! A very common use-case is calling this method from the part module OnAwake() method.
Unless the implementing class is sealed, the method must be declared as virtual. The descendants may want to react on the callback as well.

member.name: T:KSPDev.GUIUtils.GuiWindow
member.summary: A utility class to deal with the GUI windows.
member.remarks: The stock window cancels dragging when the window layout is changed. It makes it useless when dealing with windows that can change their layout depending on the position. This method doesn't have this drawback. Moreover, it can tell if the window is being dragged, so that the code could postpone the layout update until the dragging is over.

member.name: F:KSPDev.GUIUtils.GuiWindow.dragPosition
member.summary: Latest mouse position to which the dragged window position has updated.
member.remarks: When this field is null, it means no window is being dragged.

member.name: M:KSPDev.GUIUtils.GuiWindow.DragWindow(UnityEngine.Rect@,UnityEngine.Rect)
member.summary: Makes the window movable. It's an improved version of the stock GUI.DragWindow() method.
member.remarks: The main difference from the stock method is that the dragging state is not reset by the GUI layout methods. Also, it reports the draggign state, so some updates to the dialog may be frozen to not inerfere with the move operation.
member.param: The window rectangle. It must be the same instance which is passed to the GUILayout.Window method.
The rectangle in the local windows's space that defines the dragging area. In case of it's out of bounds of the window rectangle, it will be clipped.
member.returns: true if the window is being dragged.

member.name: T:KSPDev.GUIUtils.IHasContextMenu
member.summary: Generic interface for the modules that implement a UI context menu.

member.name: M:KSPDev.GUIUtils.IHasContextMenu.UpdateContextMenu
member.summary: A callback which is called every time the module's context menu items need to update.

remarks.para: When a part needs to update its context menu, it must not be doing it in the methods other this one. By doing the update in a single method, the part ensures there will be a consistency.

It's very implementation dependent when and why the update is needed. However, at the very least this callback must be called from the OnLoad method to let the module to update the state and the titles.

The method implemenation must expect to be called at any arbitrary moment of the module's life. If there are members that can be null, then they must be checked in this method to not throw an NPE. A special attention should be paid in the implementations that depend on the other modules since this method can get called when they are not initialized or created yet.
Unless the implementing class is sealed, the method must be declared as virtual. The descendants may want to react on the callback as well.

member.name: T:KSPDev.GUIUtils.LocalizableMessage
member.summary: Base class for the messages that support localization.

remarks.para: This class is not intended for the use on its own. See the inheritance hierarchy for the classes that inherit it.
This class is performance optimized. Once a string is resolved to the localized content, it's cached and reused in the subsequent calls. The cache can be reset by incrementing the .

The template of the messages supports special tags that may give a hint to the caller code on how the messages should be rendered. Those tags must be palced at the beginning of the template. For the available tags see .

member.name: T:KSPDev.GUIUtils.LocalizationLoader
member.summary: A utility class to localize the annotated members

remarks.para: It also monitors if the localization version has changed. If this is the case, then all the localizable modules will be notified.
This module is initialized from the KSPDev Utils loader.

member.name: M:KSPDev.GUIUtils.LocalizationLoader.LoadItemsInModule(PartModule)
member.summary: Localizes the items.

remarks.para:
The localizable items must be declared as non-static public members. The following items are supported:
. This type may have multiple localization items: for guiName (spec=null) and for guiUnits (spec=).
.
.
The original KSP attributes don't need to specify guiName field since it will be overwritten anyway. However, it's a good idea to give a default value just in case.
This method can be called at any time during the module's life. However, the method looks the most appropriate.

member.param: The module instance to localize.

member.name: T:KSPDev.GUIUtils.ScreenMessaging
member.summary: Helper class to present global UI messages.
member.remarks:
The actual representation of the different priority messages depends on the KSP version. As a rule of thumb use the following reasons when deciding how to show a message:
Important messages should be show as "priority". It's assumed that UI layout is build so what that such messages won't be missed.
Messages that only give status update and can be safely ignored by the player should be reported as "info". They will show up in UI but not necessarily bring user's attention.

member.name: T:KSPDev.GUIUtils.HintOverlay
member.summary: A wrapper class to present a simple overlay window with some text.

remarks.para: The overlay windows don't have a border or title. The main purpose of such windows is present the "hints". I.e. short a lived piece of information presented for the current context. The hint won't be shown in UI until explicitly requsted via a call to the ShowAt* method.
Keep in mind that this window resources will be destroyed when the scene is re-loaded. I.e. the hint window must be re-created on every scene change.

member.name: F:KSPDev.GUIUtils.HintOverlay.BackgroundTextureSize
member.summary: Size of the sample texture that fills hint window backgroud.
member.remarks: Small values may impact rendering performance. Large values will increase memory footpring. Choose it wise.

member.summary: Padding when showing hint on the right side of the mouse cursor.

member.name: F:KSPDev.GUIUtils.HintOverlay.LeftSideMousePadding
member.summary: Padding when showing hint on the left side of the mouse cursor.

member.summary: Precalculated UI text size for the currently assigned text.

member.name: F:KSPDev.GUIUtils.HintOverlay.hintWindowStyle
member.summary: Precalculated style for the hint overlay window.

member.summary: Texture to use as the hint background.
member.remarks: It's important to keep a reference to it in a C# realm. Since otherwise it will be GC'ed by Unity that doesn't recognize references from the GUIStyle objects. As of Unity 2019.2.2.

member.summary: Constructs an overaly.
member.param: Size of the text font in the hint.
Padding between the text and the window boundaries.
Color of the hint text.
Color of the hint background. If alpha component is different from 1.0 then background will be semi-transparent.

member.name: M:KSPDev.GUIUtils.HintOverlay.ShowAtCursor
member.summary: Shows hint text at the current mouse pointer.
member.remarks: When possible the window is shown on the right side of the cursor. Though, if part of the window goes out of the screen then it will be shown on the left side. If bottom boundary of the window hits bottom boundary of the screen then hint is aligned vertically so what the full content is visible.

member.name: M:KSPDev.GUIUtils.HintOverlay.ShowAtPosition(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Shows hint at the absolute screen position.
member.remarks:
If hint content goes out of the screen it's clipped.
This method must be called from the OnGUI() method.
member.param: X position is screen coordinates.
Y position is screen coordinates.

member.summary: Creates a clear color texture to fill background with.
member.param: A background color.

member.name: P:KSPDev.GUIUtils.HintOverlay.text
member.summary: The hint overlay text.
member.remarks: Linefeed symbols are correctly handled. Use them to make multiline content. Setting text is an expensive operation since it results in window size recalculation. Don't update it more frequently than the underlaying data does.
member.value: The text to be show as a hint.

The arguments can be complex types that override the ToString() method. This approach can be used to customize the output format of the specific argument types. E.g. such values as "distance" can be formatted in a user friendly manner using .

member.name: T:KSPDev.GUIUtils.GuiActionsList
member.summary: A helper to accumulate GUI actions.
member.remarks: Unity may issue multiple GUI passes during a frame, and it requires the number of UI elements not to change between the passes. Unity expects the number of UI controls in every pass to be exactly the same as in the very first one: EventType.Layout. When the UI interactions affect the representation, all the changes must be postponed till the frame rendering is ended. This helper can be used to store the actions that will be executed at the beginning of the next frame.

example.para: If you were using simple approach and updated showLabel right away Unity would likely thrown an error like this:

para.c: [EXCEPTION] ArgumentException: Getting control 1's position in a group with only 1 controls when doing Repaint

member.name: F:KSPDev.GUIUtils.GuiActionsList.guiActions
member.summary: A list of pending actions.

member.name: M:KSPDev.GUIUtils.GuiActionsList.Add(System.Action)
member.summary: Adds an action to the pending list.
member.param: An action callback.

member.name: M:KSPDev.GUIUtils.GuiActionsList.ExecutePendingGuiActions
member.summary: Executes actions when it's safe to do the changes.
member.remarks: It's safe to call this method in every pass. It will detect when it's safe to apply the changes and apply the changes only once per a frame.
member.returns: true if actions have been applied.

member.name: M:KSPDev.GUIUtils.TypeFormatters.CostType.Format(System.Double,System.String)
member.summary: Formats the value into a human friendly string.

remarks.para: The method tries to keep the resulted string meaningful and as short as possible. For this reason the big values may be scaled down and/or rounded.

There is no well established unit for measuring the costs in the game. However, there is a commonly used literal that denotes the costs: . This literal is used as the base (and the only) unit name. It's assumed that the values below 0.01 don't makes sense from the financial perspective, so they are not attempted to be presented.

member.param: The numeric value to format.
The specific float number format to use. If the format is not specified, then it's choosen basing on the value.

member.summary: Returns a string formatted as a human friendly volume specification.

member.name: M:KSPDev.GUIUtils.TypeFormatters.DistanceType.Format(System.Double,System.Nullable{System.Double},System.String)
member.summary: Formats the value into a human friendly string with a unit specification.
member.remarks: The method tries to keep the resulted string meaningful and as short as possible. For this reason the big values may be scaled down and/or rounded.
member.param: The unscaled numeric value to format.

The fixed scale to apply to the value before formatting. The formatting method can uderstand only a few scales:
Meters: scale=1.0. It's a base distance unit in the game.
Kilometers: scale=1.0e+3.

member.name: T:KSPDev.GUIUtils.UISoundPlayer
member.summary: Helper class to play sounds in the game GUI. Such sounds are not 3D aligned.

remarks.para: Use this player when the source of the sound is a GUI object (e.g. a GUI control). This class implements all the boilerplate to load and play the sound resources. All the sounds are cached within the scene, so repeating requests to the same sound won't add extra latency.
If latency is ciritcal for the caller, then the sound resource can be pre-cached via the method. It will increase the scene loading time, though.
This module is initialized from the KSPDev Utils loader.

member.name: F:KSPDev.GUIUtils.UISoundPlayer.audioCache
member.summary: Global scene cache for all the sounds.

member.name: M:KSPDev.GUIUtils.UISoundPlayer.Play(System.String)
member.summary: Plays the specified sound.
member.remarks: Every request is cached, so that the subsequent calls to play the same sound won't require the audio clip to load. However, the same cached sound cannot be played simultaneously from the different calls - each call will abort the previous play action of the sound.
member.param: The file path relative to GameData. It can be empty, in which case nothing is played.

member.name: M:KSPDev.GUIUtils.UISoundPlayer.CacheSound(System.String)
member.summary: Loads the sound into cache but doesn't play it.
member.remarks: Use this method when the sound is expected to be frequently played in the scene. However, it it only makes sense to pre-cache a resource if the first usage of the sound is a latency critical. The latency difference is not hight enough to be significant for the GUI actions.
member.param: File path relative to GameData.

member.name: M:KSPDev.GUIUtils.UISoundPlayer.Awake
member.summary: Initializes the .
member.remarks: It's expected to be called only once.

member.name: M:KSPDev.GUIUtils.UISoundPlayer.GetOrLoadAudio(System.String)
member.summary: Loads the audio sample and plays it.
member.param: The file path relative to GameData.
member.returns: An audio resource if loaded or found in the cache, otherwise null.

member.name: P:KSPDev.GUIUtils.UISoundPlayer.instance
member.summary: Returns the instance of the player in the current scene.

member.name: T:KSPDev.InputUtils.EventChecker
member.summary: A helper to verify various event handling conditions.

member.name: M:KSPDev.InputUtils.EventChecker.IsModifierCombinationPressed(KSPDev.InputUtils.KeyModifiers)
member.summary: Verifies that the requested key modifiers are pressed.
member.remarks:
The check will succeed only if the exact set of modifier keys is pressed. If there are more or less modifiers pressed the check will fail. E.g. if there are LeftAlt and LeftShift pressed but the check is executed against AnyShift then it will fail. Though, checking for AnyShift | AnyAlt will succeed.
In case of checking for None the check will require no modifier keys to be pressed. If you deal with mouse button events it's a good idea to verify if no modifiers are pressed even if you don't care about other combinations. It will let other modders to use mouse buttons and not to interfere with your mod.
member.param: A combination of key modifiers to verify.
member.returns: true when exactly the requested combination is pressed.

member.name: M:KSPDev.InputUtils.EventChecker.CheckLeftSymmetricalModifiers(UnityEngine.Event)
member.summary: Verifies if the left-side "symmetrical" keyboard modifiers, defined in the event, are currently in effect (pressed and hold). The exact match is required.
member.remarks: The "symmetrical modifiers" are modifier keys that are represented on the both sides of a standard 101-key keyboard and, thus, have "left" and "right" keys. These are: ALT, CTRL, SHIFT, and COMMAND.

member.name: M:KSPDev.InputUtils.EventChecker.CheckRightSymmetricalModifiers(UnityEngine.Event)
member.summary: Verifies if the right-side "symmetrical" keyboard modifiers, defined in the event, are currently in effect (pressed and hold). The exact match is required.
member.remarks: The "symmetrical modifiers" are modifier keys that are represented on the both sides of a standard 101-key keyboard and, thus, have "left" and "right" keys. These are: ALT, CTRL, SHIFT, and COMMAND.

member.name: M:KSPDev.InputUtils.EventChecker.CheckAnySymmetricalModifiers(UnityEngine.Event)
member.summary: Verifies if any of the "symmetrical" keyboard modifiers, defined in the event, are currently in effect (pressed and hold). The exact match is required.
member.remarks: The "symmetrical modifiers" are modifier keys that are represented on the both sides of a standard 101-key keyboard and, thus, have "left" and "right" keys. These are: ALT, CTRL, SHIFT, and COMMAND.

member.name: M:KSPDev.InputUtils.EventChecker.GetInputButtonFromEvent(UnityEngine.Event)
member.summary: Extracts mouse button from a keyboard event definition.
member.remarks: Only three basic buttons are supported: Left, Right, and Middle.
member.param: The event to extract the button from.
member.returns: The button or null if event doesn't have any recognizable mouse button.

member.name: M:KSPDev.InputUtils.EventChecker.CheckClickEvent(UnityEngine.Event,System.Nullable{UnityEngine.EventSystems.PointerEventData.InputButton})
member.summary: Checks if the mouse click event has happen during the frame.
member.remarks: This check treats "left" and "right" modifiers equally. And it doesn't consider any of the state modifiers (CAPS, NUM, SCROLL, etc.).
member.param: The event to match for.
The mouse button that was clicked. If this parameter is omitted, then only the event modifiers are checked. It can be used to check the "pre-condition".
member.returns: true if the requested combination has matched the current frame state.

member.name: T:KSPDev.InputUtils.KeyboardInputSwitch
member.summary: Wrapper around a keyboard key code that incapsulates the persiting and the handling logic into a single class.

remarks.para: The fields of this type are correctly handled by the stock game persisting functionality (). It's also compatible with the KSPDev persisting logic ().

Important! This type will be correctly loaded or saved by the KSP core but it will not be correctly copied in the game's editor. It's not an issue when the field is static but in case of it's an instance member, the code must not be accessing it in the editor mode.

example.para: To define a key binding just create a class with the key code as a parameter, and notify the switch about the frame updates so that it could update its state:
In case of the switch state needs to be checked from the other methods use property:
When the code needs to react to a switch state event, it can register a listener:
In many cases you may want to load a key bining from a config file. It can be achieved by adding an attribute to the field of this type:

member.summary: Tells if any switch is being hold.
member.remarks: This value is a version specific. I.e. the multiple versions of the utils DLL will not see each other. So, if this property returns true then the only safe assumption is that any switch within the running mod is being hold. Ideally, when all the mods in the game run the same version of the utils DLL, this property will truly say if any in the game is in the hold state.

member.name: T:KSPDev.KSPInterfaces.IPartModule
member.summary: Interface for KSP part module.

remarks.para: Naturally, KSP doesn't declare any part module interface (unfortunately), and all modder's modules just inherit from . This interface is introduced for the better OOP approach. It reveals methods that a regular module can override, and provides documentation for each of them.
Some methods of the module interface look familiar to the ones from Unity but they are not behaving in the same way in every scene. Moreover, not all methods get called in every scene.
In the loading scene the callbacks are executed in the following order:

item.description: Notifies about creating new module. If it's a clone operation then all annotated fields have values from the part's config. Otherwise, all the fields are in the initial states.
The provided config node is the original configuration from the part's definition. All the annotated fields are populated before this method gets control.
Is not called since the parts being created are prefabs and icon models. They are not real parts that behave on a vessel.

remarks.para: In the editor the callbacks are executed in the following order:

item.description:
Notifies about creating new module. If it's a clone operation then all annotated fields have values from the part's config. Otherwise, all the fields are in the initial states.
New parts in the editor are created via the clone operation. I.e. each time a part is dragged from the toolbar it's get cloned from the prefab.

Is not called for the new parts since they are clonned. When a saved vessel is loaded in the editor every part on the vessel gets this method called with the values from the save file. The annotated fields are populated from the file before this method gets control, so it's safe to use them.
Hard to say what it means for the edtior, but important difference from the flight scenes is that this method is called before .
The code must check if the current scene is editor, and do the behavior changes as needed. In the editor parts must not have active behavior.

remarks.para: In the fligth scenes the callbacks are executed in the following order:

item.description: Notifies about creating new module. All annotated fields have initial values.
The provided config node is the config from the save file. The annotated fields are populated from the file before this method gets control, so it's safe to use them.
This method is called when all parts in the vessel are created and loaded. The code must check if the current scene is flight, and do the behavior changes as needed.

Indicates that part should start handling physics if any. It may be called multiple times during the part's life. First time it's called when vessel is completely loaded in the secene and all parts are started. Other calls may happen when game returns from a physics suspended state (e.g. from a warp mode back to x1 time speed).
Code must check if editor scene is loaded since this method is called differently in the editor.

member.name: M:KSPDev.KSPInterfaces.IPartModule.OnAwake
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the module on the part.
member.remarks:
Called on a newly created part. Note, that this method is a bad place to interact with the other modules on the part since module initialization order is not defined.
See more details on the calling sequence in .

member.name: M:KSPDev.KSPInterfaces.IPartModule.OnLoad(ConfigNode)
member.summary: Notifies that the part's config is loaded.
member.remarks:
All the fields annotated by are already loaded at this moment. Use the node from this method to handle special values that are not supported by KSP.
See more details on the calling sequence in .
member.param: Either the part's config node or a configuration from a save file.

member.name: M:KSPDev.KSPInterfaces.IPartModule.OnStart(PartModule.StartState)
member.summary: Initializes module's state after all other modules have been created.
member.remarks: Note, that this is not the right place to start physics on the part. This callback is good to acquire references to the the other modules on the part, and for establishing the internal state of the module.
member.para: See more details on the calling sequence in .
member.param: State that specifies the situation of the vessel.

member.name: M:KSPDev.KSPInterfaces.IPartModule.OnStartFinished(PartModule.StartState)
member.summary: Notifies that all the modules on the part have been started.
member.remarks: This is the right place to interact with the other modules on the part. At this moment they all are assumed to be properly setup.
member.param: State that specifies the situation of the vessel.

member.name: M:KSPDev.KSPInterfaces.IPartModule.OnInitialize
member.summary: Called on a vessel when it's time to start the physics on it.
member.remarks: It can be called multiple times during the part's life.

member.name: M:KSPDev.KSPInterfaces.IPartModule.OnUpdate
member.summary: Notifies about a frame update.
member.remarks: Be very careful about placing functionality into this callback even if it's bare "if/else" statement. This callback is called on every frame update. It means that even a simple piece of code will be called for every part that implements the module. Too many parts with such modules may significantly drop FPS.

member.name: M:KSPDev.KSPInterfaces.IPartModule.OnFixedUpdate
member.summary: Notifies about a physics frame update.
member.remarks:
Physics in Unity is updated every 20ms which gives 50 calls per a second. Be extremly careful about placing functionality into this callback. All fixed updates are required to complete, so if 50 updates take longer than one second then the game's speed will degrade.
In general, don't even override this callback unless it's absolutely required.

member.name: M:KSPDev.KSPInterfaces.IPartModule.OnSave(ConfigNode)
member.summary: Notifies about saving module state.
member.remarks:
This isn't required to be saving into a real file. This method is a generic way to save module state when it's needed. Note, that saving null is usually a problem for KSP, so always give default non-null values to every persisted field.
Persistent fields annotated woth are saved before this callback is called. Only save values that need special handling.
member.param: Config node to save data into.

member.name: M:KSPDev.ModelUtils.Colliders.SetSimpleCollider(UnityEngine.GameObject,UnityEngine.PrimitiveType,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Drops the colliders in all the children objects, and adds one big collider to the parent.
member.remarks:
The main purpose of this method is to create one fast collider at the cost of precision. All the meshes in the object (the parent and the children) are processed to produce a single boundary box. Then, this box is applied to the requested primitive type that defines the shape of the final collider.
Note, that radius of the sphere and the capsule colliders is the same on both X and Y axis. If the combined boundary box has any of the dimensions significantly different then it makes sense to choose a different collider type. Or break down the hirearchy into more colliders.
member.param: Parent object.
Type of the primitive which describes the parent object most precise in terms of the shape. Only , , , and are supported. The two latter types produce in the same collider type - the capsule.

When calculating the total volume of the object, all its meshes produce a single box boundary. Then, the collider either wraps this box entirely, or sits inside it entirely. If this parameter is true then the collider will cover the boundary box.

member.name: M:KSPDev.ModelUtils.Hierarchy.FindTransformByPath(UnityEngine.Transform,System.String,UnityEngine.Transform)
member.summary: Finds a transform in the hirerachy by the provided path.
member.remarks: See the path format in .
member.param: The transfrom to start looking from.
The path to the target. The name components must be escaped if they contain the special symbols.

member.name: M:KSPDev.ModelUtils.Hierarchy.FindTransformByPath(UnityEngine.Transform,System.String[],UnityEngine.Transform)
member.summary: Finds a transform in the hirerachy by the provided path.
member.remarks:
Every element of the path may specify an exact transform name or a partial match pattern:
To find an element that contains symbol / (the path components separator), simply double it. E.g. "a//b" will be looking for component, named "a/b" instead fo seacrhing for child "b" in the parent "a".
* - any name matches. Such patterns can be nested to specify the desired level of nesting. E.g. */*/a will look for name a in the grandchildren.
* as a prefix - the name is matched by suffix. E.g. *a matches any name that ends with a.
* as a suffix - the name is matched by prefix. E.g. a* matches any name that starts with a.
** - any path matches. What will eventually be found depends on the pattern to the right of **. E.g. **/a/b will go through all the nodes starting from the parent until path a/b is found. If multiple paths have matched the pattern, then the shortest path will be returned. Be careful with this pattern since in case of not matching anything it will walk thought the whole hirerachy, starting from .
All patterns except ** may have a matching index. It can be used to resolve matches when there are multiple objects found with the same name and at the same level. E.g. if there are two objects with name "a" at the root level then the first one can be accessed by pattern a:0, and the second one by pattern a:1.
Path search is slow since it needs walking though the hierarchy nodes. In the worst case all the nodes will be visited. Don't use this method in the performance demanding methods.
member.param: The transfrom to start looking from.
The path elements. All the special symbols must be unescaped.
An object to return if the path is not found. This situation will be treated as a danger, and a warning log record will be made.
member.returns: Transform or null if nothing found.

member.summary: Destroys the object in a way which is safe for physical callback methods.

And it may trigger physics before the final cleanup. This method ensures that none of these side-effects happen and it doesn't use physics incompatible DestroyImmediate method.

member.name: M:KSPDev.ModelUtils.Meshes.RescaleTextureToLength(UnityEngine.GameObject,System.Single,UnityEngine.Renderer)
member.summary: Rescales texture so what one sample covers exactly one unit of the primitive length.
member.remarks:
Normally one texture sample covers the whole primitive regardless to its length. By calling this method you ensure that one sample keeps its ratio comparing to a linear unit. If primitive is too short to fit the texture then the texture is truncated. If primitive is too long to be covered by one sample then the texture will be tiled to fill the space.
This methods assumes UV data on the primitive was created for a length of 1m. With this assumption in mind the Z axis of the local scale is cosidered "the length". method guarantees that newly created primitive always has length of one meter but if primitive was created by other means its default length can be different.
member.param: Game object to adjust material on. Z axis scale gives the length.
Length to be completly covered by one sample of the texture.

Specific renderer to adjust texture in. If null then first renderer on the object will be updated. Note, that getting renderer from the object is an expensive operation. When performance is the key it makes sense caching the renderer, and passing it in every rescale call.

New shader name. If null then it will not be changed.
Color to set. If null then it will not be changed.

This module implements common logic to deal with part's configuration, persistence and localization.
The descendants of this module can use the custom persistent fields of groups:

member.name: M:KSPDev.PartUtils.AbstractPartModule.CheckSettingsConsistency
member.summary: Verifies that all part's settings are consistent.
member.remarks:
If there are contradicting settings detected, they must be fixed so that the part could behave consistently. A warning must be logged to point out what was fixed and to what value.
Implementations may call this method multiple times at different stages. At the very least it's called on the module load, but this must not be assumed the only use-case.

member.name: M:KSPDev.PartUtils.AbstractPartModule.ShowStatusMessage(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Shows a UI messages with regard to the currently active vessel.
member.remarks: The UI messages from the active vessel are shown at the highest priority to bring attention of the player. The messages from the inactive vessels are shown only as a status, that is not intended to distract the player from the current vessel operations.
member.param: The message to show.
Tells if the messages is an error condition report. Such messages will be highlighed.

member.name: M:KSPDev.PartUtils.AbstractPartModule.InitModuleSettings
member.summary: Initializes the module state according to the settings.
member.remarks:
This method is normally called from OnLoad method, when all the part components are created, but some of them may be not initialized yet. Under some circumstances it can be called from the OnStart method (e.g. in the editor or when loading an inconsistent save file).
This method is a good place for the module to become aware of the other part modules, but it's not the right place to deal with the other module settings.
This method can be called multiple times in the part's life time, so keep this method ideponent. Repetative calls to this method should not break the part's logic.

member.name: M:KSPDev.PartUtils.PartModel.UpdateHighlighters(UnityEngine.Transform)
member.summary: Refreshes the highlighters on the part that owns the provided model.
member.remarks: When a part is highlighted (e.g. due to the mouse hover event), it highlights its models via a pre-cached set of the highlighter components. This cache is constructed on the part creation. If a model is added or removed from the part in runtime, the cache needs to be updated. This method does it by finding the part from the game objects hirerachy. If there is a part found, then its highlighters are updated.
member.param: The game object which needs an update. It can be null.

member.name: M:KSPDev.PartUtils.PartModel.UpdateHighlighters(Part)
member.summary: Refreshes the highlighters on the part.
member.remarks: It goes thru the highlighters cache and drops all the renderers that are no more in the part's model hierarchy. Then, it gets all the renderers in the hierarchy and ensures all of them are in the cache. It's not a cheap operation performance wise.
member.param: The part to refresh the highlighters for. It can be null.

member.summary: Returns an event for the requested method.
member.remarks: This method requests a KPS event of the part's module by its signature instead of a string literal name. The same result could be achieved by accessing the Events field of the PartModule object. However, in case of using a string literal the refactoring and the source tracking tools won't be able to track the reference. The main goal of this method is to provide a compile time checking mechanism for the cases when the exact method is known at the compile time (e.g. in the class descendants).

member.name: T:KSPDev.PrefabUtils.PrefabLoader
member.summary: Utility class to load Unity assets and bundles into the game in runtime.
member.remarks: This module works best in conjunction with the UnityDev library. The dynamic assets can be loaded via this utility, and UnityDev can be used to retrieve the assets.

member.name: M:KSPDev.PrefabUtils.PrefabLoader.LoadAsset``1(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads an asset from the specified bundle.
member.remarks: The loaded bundles are cached, so multiple calls for the same bundle won't impact performance or cause errors.
member.typeparam: The type of component to retrieve from the prefab object. If it's GameObject, then the prefab itself is returned.
member.param: The full path to the bundle.
The prefab name. It can be a GameObject name, or it can be a full Unity path to the object, which lets avoiding name collisions.

If true, then method InitPrefab will be attempted to invoke on all the components of the loaded prefab. The method can be instance or static, but it must be public. If the method is absent, it's not an error. Use this ability if Unity prefabs need some setup before being exposed to the game.
member.returns: The component of type . Can be null if the prefab cannot be found or the bundle cannot be loaded.

member.name: M:KSPDev.PrefabUtils.PrefabLoader.LoadAllAssets(System.String)
member.summary: Loads and initializes all the assets from the bundle file.
member.remarks:
This method extracts all prefabs from teh asset file and makes them availabe to the game. It also looks for method InitPrefab() thru all the components of at the root prefab object, and invokes it if found. This method can be implemented by the components to bring the prefab into a "default" state.
Every asset bundle is loaded exactly one time and cached. Repetative calls for the same bundle will be NO-OP.
member.returns: true if bundle has been successfully loaded or found in cache.
member.param: The full path to the bundle.

member.name: M:KSPDev.PrefabUtils.PrefabLoader.GetOrLoadBundle(System.String)
member.summary: Returns a bundle either from the cache or loads it.
member.param: The full path to the bundle.
member.returns: The asset bundle or null if cannot be loaded.

member.name: M:KSPDev.PrefabUtils.PrefabLoader.GetCachedBundle(System.String)
member.summary: Lookups the bundle in the cache.
member.remarks: Only bundles loaded thru KSPDev are considered.
member.param: The full path to the bundle.
member.returns: The asset bundle or null if none found in the cache.

member.name: T:KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.AsyncCall
member.summary: Set of tools to execute a delayed code.
member.remarks: Use these tools when the code needs to be executed with some delay or at the specific moment of time.

member.name: M:KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.AsyncCall.CallOnEndOfFrame(UnityEngine.MonoBehaviour,System.Action,System.Int32)
member.summary: Delays execution of the delegate till the end of the frame.
member.remarks: The delegate will trigger at the end of the selected frame update. If is set to 0, then the delegate will be called at the end of the current frame. Calling this method in the "end of frame" callback will not schedule the callback on the next frame, the execution will just be placed at the end of the current frame execution queue. This behavior can be used to execute a logic that depends on some other delayed logic. In order to schedule the execution on the frame different from the current, specify the parameter.
member.param: The Unity object to run the coroutine on. If this object dies, then the async call will not be invoked.
The delegate to execute.
The number of frames to skip.

member.name: M:KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.AsyncCall.CallOnTimeout(UnityEngine.MonoBehaviour,System.Single,System.Action)
member.summary: Delays execution of the delegate for the specified amount of time.
member.remarks: The delegate will be called when the timeout is expired.
member.param: The Unity object to run the coroutine on. If this object dies, then the async call will not be invoked.
The timeout in seconds.
The delegate to execute.

member.name: M:KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.AsyncCall.CallOnFixedUpdate(UnityEngine.MonoBehaviour,System.Action,System.Int32)
member.summary: Delays execution of the delegate till the next fixed update.
member.remarks: The delegate will be called during the following fixed (physics) update.
member.param: The Unity object to run the coroutine on. If this object dies, then the async call will not be invoked.
The delegate to execute.
The number of fixed frames to skip.

member.name: M:KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.AsyncCall.WaitForPhysics(UnityEngine.MonoBehaviour,System.Int32,System.Func{System.Boolean},System.Action,System.Action,System.Action{System.Int32})
member.summary: Delays execution until the specified condition is reached. Waiting is limited by the specified number of fixed frame updates.
member.remarks: Can be used when the code expects some specific physical state of the game. The method allows to define for how long to wait, what to do while waiting, and what to execute when target state is reached or missed.
member.param: The Unity object to run the coroutine on. If this object dies, then the async call will not be invoked.
The number of fixed frame updates to wait before giving up.

The state checking function. It should return true once the target state is reached. The very first execution happens immediately on the method call, before exiting from the method. If this execution returns true, then the successful callback is also called immediately.
The callback to execute when the state has been successfully reached.
The callabck to execute when the state has not been reached before the frame update limit is exhausted.

The callback to execute every fixed frame update while waiting. This callabck will be called at least once, and the first call happens immediately. The argument tells how many frames the method was waiting so far. For the very first call it's 0.

member.name: M:KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.AsyncCall.AsyncWaitForPhysics(System.Int32,System.Func{System.Boolean},System.Action,System.Action,System.Action{System.Int32})
member.summary: Async version of .
member.param: The number of fixed frame updates to wait before giving up.

The state checking function. It should return true once the target state is reached. The very first execution happens immediately on the method call, before exiting from the method. If this execution returns true, then the successful callback is also called immediately.
The callback to execute when the state has been successfully reached.
The callabck to execute when the state has not been reached before the frame update limit is exhausted.

The callback to execute every fixed frame update while waiting. This callabck will be called at least once, and the first call happens immediately. The argument tells how many frames the method was waiting so far. For the very first call it's 0.
member.returns: The enumerator that can be used as a coroutine target.

member.name: T:KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.SimpleStateMachine`1
member.summary: Simple state machine that allows tracking of the states and checking the basic transition conditions.
member.remarks: If a module has more that two modes (which can be controlled by a simple boolean) it makes sense to define each mode as a state, and introduce a definite state transition diagram. Once it's done, a state machine can be setup by defining which transitions are allowed. At this point the module will be able to just react on the state change events instead of checking multiple conditions.
member.typeparam: The enum to use as the state constants.

member.name: M:KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.SimpleStateMachine`1.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructs a new uninitialized state machine.
member.param: Tells if all the transitions must be explicitly declared.

member.name: M:KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.SimpleStateMachine`1.SetTransitionConstraint(`0,`0[])
member.summary: Defines a state and the allowed target states for it.
member.remarks: In the strict mode it's required that every transition is declared excplicitly.
member.param: The source state.
The list of the states that are allowed as the targets.

member.name: M:KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.SimpleStateMachine`1.ResetTransitionConstraint(`0)
member.summary: Clears the transitions for the source state if any.
member.param: The source state to clear the tarnsitions for.

member.name: M:KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.SimpleStateMachine`1.AddStateHandlers(`0,KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.SimpleStateMachine{`0}.OnChange,KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.SimpleStateMachine{`0}.OnChange,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adds a state change event.

remarks.para: When the state is changed by setting the property, the transition callbacks are only called when the state has actually changed.
Note, that the code must not expect that the handlers will be called in the same order as they were added. Each handler must be independent from the others.

member.param: The state to call a callback on.

The callback to call when the state machine has switched to a new state. The callback is triggered after the state has actually changed. The callback's parameter is the old state, from which the machine has switched.

The callback to call when the state machine is going to leave the current state. The callback is triggered before the state has actually changed. The callback's parameter is the new state, to which the machine is going to switch.

Tells if this handler is allowed to be called when the state machine intitates from the null state. This usually means the owning object is in process of loading its state. Not all functionality can be availabe at this moment.
Tells if this handler is allowed to be called when the state machine goes into the null state. This usually means execution of the cleanup code, and the state of the owning object can be reduced.

member.name: M:KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.SimpleStateMachine`1.RemoveHandlers(`0,KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.SimpleStateMachine{`0}.OnChange,KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.SimpleStateMachine{`0}.OnChange)
member.summary: Removes a state change event handler.
member.remarks: It's safe to call it for a non-existing handler.
member.param: The state to delete a handler for.
The enter state handler to delete.
The leave state handler to delete.

member.summary: Verifies if the machine can move into the desired state.
member.param: The state to check the transition for.

member.summary: Verifies that the state machine is started.

member.summary: Notifies all the handlers about entering a new state.

member.summary: Notifies the transitions listeners about the state change.

The new state which the machine is entering.
Tells if the transition is about to happen or has already happen.

member.name: P:KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.SimpleStateMachine`1.currentState
member.summary: Current state of the machine.

remarks.para: Setting the same state as the current one is a NO-OP. Setting of a new state may throw an exception in the strict mode.

The initial state is always null, whih means STOPPED. The caller must set the initial state before starting using the machine. In spite of the other transitions, the initial state change is not restricted by the state transition constraints, regardless to the setting.
To STOP the machine, just set the current state to null. No "enter state" handlers will be executed in this case, but all the "leave state" handlers will do their job.

member.value: The current state. It can be null.

member.name: P:KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.SimpleStateMachine`1.isStrict
member.summary: Tells if all the transitions must be excplicitly declared.

member.name: E:KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.SimpleStateMachine`1.onBeforeTransition
member.summary: Event that fires before the state machine has changed its state.
member.remarks: The event is fired before the new state has been applied to the state machine and the transition callbacks are called, but after the transition validation is done. I.e. this event won't trigger if the transition failed due to the constraints.

member.name: E:KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.SimpleStateMachine`1.onAfterTransition
member.summary: Event that fires when the state machine has changed its state.
member.remarks: The event is fired after the new state has been applied to the state machine and all the transition callbacks are handled.

member.name: T:KSPDev.ProcessingUtils.SimpleStateMachine`1.OnStateChangeHandler
member.summary: Delegate to track an arbitrary state transition.
member.param: The state before the change.
The state after the change.

member.name: T:KSPDev.Types.PosAndRot
member.summary: Type to hold position and rotation of a transform. It can be serialized.
member.remarks:
The value serializes into 6 numbers separated by a comma. They form two triplets:
The first triplet is a position: x, y, z.
The second triplet is a Euler rotation around each axis: x, y, z.

member.para: By default position is (0,0,0), Euler angles are (0,0,0), and the rotation is Quaternion.identity.
